channel.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
channel.description: Ok so I've finally go enough money for a good psu and a good video card. So I want to know what your guys opinions are for videocards. I can spend up to $350. I wan't this card to be future proof for at least a year. It would be nice to run crysis 2 that is coming out in december at decent settings but if you guys think that any $350 dollar card now won't be able to run it decently in december then I will just wait. I don't care if it is Nvidia or ATI I just want the best deal for the money I am spending.

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

Enjoy your overclocked rebranded 4xxx.

http://www.techpowerup.com/reviews/NVIDIA/GeForce_GTX_480_SLI/ (31 pages)

Just still saying you should have gone with nvidia, and the 5870 get as hot as the 480’s (I had the picture I just cannot find it after reformatting).

You could have gone with a GTX295 and still have gotten a card that is almost as good as the 5870.

Read full topic

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:60, topic:344997”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=441374.msg3246237#msg3246237 date=1277394492]

I’m with lawl, my current case (which I got for free) is sturdy, looks awesome (kind of like a dragon), and has great air flow. I’ve been using it since 06 with no problems. I’ve also spent $20 on shitty cases, but like I said, there is no such thing as an airflow problem that a drill and a saw can’t fix with a little time.

Well I went from this to this for my grandparents build and the case was only $50 at the the time (now $100) so I know exactally what you mean by nothing a drill/dremel/unchannel edging/paint can’t solve.
[/quote]
hi im 96 and onboard graphics isnt enough[/quote]
They aren’t 96 and my grandparents use the computer very often, also when I come to visit I want to do a little gaming if I get bored.

Read full topic

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:54, topic:344997”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=441374.msg3245766#msg3245766 date=1277338586]
Its on most high end expensive cases:
[/quote]

Probably why I’ve never seen one, the most expensive case I’ve ever bought was $35, the one I currently have I got for free because it was dented during delivery and newegg didn’t want to pay $20 shipping to get back a $20 case. There are just so much better things you can spend money on in a computer than a case, which, for the most part, has no effect on anything. (at least nothing a drill and a saw won’t fix)[/quote]

I totally agree about not spending alot of money on cases because I am always on a small budget, but I still want my case to look nice, be sturdy, and have decent features. If I was to actually by an expensive case I would probably reuse it and by some cheap case to throw the old build into. Although im going to have the same case probably for the next 5-6 years so…its a good investment imo.

Read full topic

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

The GTX 470 is about the same as the 5850, and the GTX 480 is about the same as the 5870.

The small gain in frames is not worth the higher price, and even more so when you take power and heat into consideration.

Read full topic
item.source: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“cumescape, post:50, topic:344997”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=441374.msg3245649#msg3245649 date=1277330598]

The 5970 is better than the 480. So what? That shouldn’t influence anyone’s decision on buying lower end cards.

The 5970 has 2 GPU’s so therefore logically it would be better. If you have seen I never once said anything about it.

Also you know how well it will do, there are plenty of benchmarks for it.

Just like you can’t compare a 5970 to a 480, you can’t compare a 5850 to a 480.
[/quote]
That would be like saying you cannot compare a single GPU to a single GPU, what are you a dumb ass? Get off the bandwagon and realize that the GTX480’s wipe the floor with the 5800’s

And I cannot wait for GTX485.[/quote]

OK, that means we can compare the 5870 to the 470 because they’re both single GPU cards. Oh the 5870 performs better therefore ATi is the best? No. What matters most to consumers is the price:performance ratio. Given the price of the 5870, it’s much better than the 480.

[img]http://tpucdn.com/reviews/NVIDIA/GeForce_GTX_480_Fermi/images/perfrel_2560.gif[/img] The 480 is 7% faster at max resolution. 7% for 50% more power and 20% more heat. It's pathetic, probably the worst card since the 2900XT, and the 470 is barely better.
Tom's Hardware

GTX 470 vs GTX 480 vs 5870 vs 5850 - Graphics Cards

I figured that there is a lot of mixed thoughts on the subject so I would like to see what people really think,and for the record I personally think the GTX 470 is the best bang for the buck, enjoy!I...

Read full topic
item.source: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range

The 5970 has 2 GPU’s so therefore logically it would be better. If you have seen I never once said anything about it.

Also you know how well it will do, there are plenty of benchmarks for it.
[/quote]

Just like you can’t compare a 5970 to a 480, you can’t compare a 5850 to a 480.[/quote]

And I cannot wait for GTX485.

item.source: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:47, topic:344997”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=441374.msg3245743#msg3245743 date=1277337442]

I’ve never seen a PSU installed at the bottom of the computer like that, odd case.

Its the new thing, almost on any new gaming case cold air is always on bottom so it makes sense right?
[/quote]

Not really, I’d rather have my CPU cooler than my PSU, and the item closer to the bottom would be cooler, so a standard case would probably be cooler.

Except that maybe having bigger fans on the top like that blowing hot air out might keep the whole box cooler. Probably 6 of one, half dozen of the other really…[/quote]

Yeah but the psu pulls in air from the bottom (their is a vent under the psu) and the exhaust out the back, on normal cases with top montuned cpu it pulls the hot our from the top of the case (air that was already inside the case) and then exausts it our the back.

Its on most high end expensive cases:

http://www.newegg.com/Product/ProductList.aspx?Submit=ENE&N=2010090007%201790749145&bop=And&ShowDeactivatedMark=False&Order=PRICED&PageSize=20

In my case it doesnt matter for the cpu, the raditor is mounted on the back of the case and it pulls air from the back across the raditor into the case, then it gets pulled out the top by two 120mm fans, there is also a vent on bottom where I can mount another 120mm fan which will pull cold air in, but I have a 140mm fan on the front which does that already. Trust me its really, really cool inside the case, even the air coming out the top is pretty cool (I plan this all out when choosing a case btw)

Read full topic
item.source: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

With the PSU being at the bottom, it draws air from underneath the case and the exhaust comes outside the case. That would improve cooling in the psu, because it draws cooler air from outside as opposed to hotter air from the inside. I don’t see how it would contribute to the temperature of the CPU. Also I would assume that it would also reduce stress on the case?

Read full topic

Not really, I’d rather have my CPU cooler than my PSU, and the item closer to the bottom would be cooler, so a standard case would probably be cooler.

Except that maybe having bigger fans on the top like that blowing hot air out might keep the whole box cooler. Probably 6 of one, half dozen of the other really…

item.title: New Graphics Card: $350 Dollar Price Range
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Radeon, post:43, topic:344997”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=441374.msg3245717#msg3245717 date=1277333808]

The 5970 is better than the 480. So what? That shouldn’t influence anyone’s decision on buying lower end cards.

The 5970 has 2 GPU’s so therefore logically it would be better. If you have seen I never once said anything about it.

Also you know how well it will do, there are plenty of benchmarks for it.

Just like you can’t compare a 5970 to a 480, you can’t compare a 5850 to a 480.

the 5850 runs mw2 easy if you wanted to know I am getting really high framerates with it at 1920x1080 with 4x antialising and all settings on the highest.
[/quote]

wonderful.

What type of cooling is that on your processor and was it necessary?[/quote]

Corsair Water Cooling No Matience Required
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16835181010&cm_re=Corsair_CPU_Cooler--35-181-010--Product

Yes, stock was fine for no overclocking, but I unlocked 2 extra cores for the quad and I overclocked it @ 3.6GHZ stable the stock settings I believe was Dual-Core @3.2GHZ
When I was using the stock cooler it was getting in the 70C and now it doesnt get above 45C

Read full topic
